metadata.title: Bridge Program: MATH 2330 Linear Algebra – Penn State Great Valley

paragraphs: Linear Algebra is your gateway to mastering the fundamental concepts and techniques of linear algebra—an essential toolkit for advancing in fields like engineering, computer science, data science, and beyond. Offered as a foundational prerequisite for the Penn State Master’s program, this course not only prepares you for graduate studies but also builds critical skills that you’ll apply throughout your academic and professional career. You’ll dive into core topics, including matrices, vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues/eigenvectors. Each module is crafted to help you grasp these concepts and confidently tackle complex problems, developing both your analytical thinking and problem-solving abilities.
Whether you’re gearing up for graduate studies or enhancing your expertise, this course provides a comprehensive, practical foundation in linear algebra.

This course is entirely asynchronous and self-paced.  The content is presented in five (5) self-paced modules.  Each module uses zyBooks for delivery of content and activities.  Information on how to access zyBooks is provided in the Course Materials section below. Students are required to read and engage with the content and complete any assigned activities or quizzes.  Students must achieve a score of 75% to be considered passing.  The modules cover the concepts below:

You will navigate through each module independently.  The content is presented through the zyBook Linear Algebra, which has been customized for you by faculty members in the Engineering Department. A zyBook is web-native interactive content that will help students learn challenging topics.
After engaging with the content and activities in each module, you will demonstrate your understanding by completing an assessment at the end of each module.
The objective of this course is to provide you with a solid understanding of linear algebra concepts.  By the end of the course, you will be able to:
Learning objectives will be measured through automatic means of:
If you have any questions or concerns, please reach out to the Engineering administrative team at Penn State Great Valley.
If you have any questions regarding the zyBook content or activities, please contact the zyBook Help CenterLinks to an external site.

Students will be evaluated by completing participation activities and quizzes that evaluate their understanding of the material presented.  You are expected to read and understand all content presented in the zyBook.  Please carefully read and engage with the content presented before attempting to complete the quiz.
You must score 80% on each quiz before advancing to the next module.  In order to pass this course, you must achieve a total score of at least 80%.
In order to complete this course, you must score at least 75% on each of the five (5) lesson quizzes.

Connect to the zyBook to complete the readings and interactive elements.  The zyBook includes Additional Exercises at the end of each section.  You are not required to complete them, but they are available should you wish to have additional practice.
The zyBook content consists of reading material and activities:
Participation Activities: Question sets and animations allow you to engage with the content and test your knowledge.
Challenge Activities: Challenge activities provide immediate feedback. These are not graded and you can attempt them as often as you like.

Additional Exercises: You’ll find additional exercises at the end of each section.  You are not required to complete the exercises, but they are provided for your benefit if you need additional practice.
You will complete an assessment at the end of each Module in the form of a multiple choice quiz.  You must score at least 75% to advance to the next Module.
*subject to change
